title: Domain 2.6: Compare and contrast common network configuration concepts.
content:
🌐 DNS (Domain Name System)

🧭 Address Records

A record – Maps a domain to an IPv4 address
AAAA record – Maps a domain to an IPv6 address

🧠 Tip: If you can’t resolve a domain name, check A/AAAA records.

📧 MX (Mail Exchanger) Record

Directs email traffic to the correct mail server for a domain.

🧠 Tip: Used by mail servers (like Gmail or Outlook) to deliver email to the right destination.

📝 TXT (Text) Record

Stores non-domain resolving info, often used for spam filtering.

🔒 Spam Management:

  • SPF – Lists authorized mail servers allowed to send on behalf of a domain
  • DKIM – Cryptographically signs messages to verify sender
  • DMARC – Tells mail servers what to do if SPF/DKIM checks fail (quarantine, reject)

🧠 Tip: If company emails go to spam, check these TXT record settings!

🧠 DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)

⏳ Leases

Temporary assignment of an IP address. Lease expires → client must renew.

🎯 Reservations

Assigns a specific IP to a device (based on MAC address). Ensures consistency (e.g., printer always gets the same IP).

🌍 Scope

The range of IPs a DHCP server can assign (e.g., 192.168.1.100–192.168.1.200)

🧠 Tip: If a device gets no IP or duplicate IP errors, check the DHCP scope or reservation table.

🧩 VLAN (Virtual LAN)

Segment a network logically without physical separation.
Devices in different VLANs act as if they’re on different switches.
Requires a managed switch.

🧠 Tip: Used to separate departments: e.g., HR VLAN, Sales VLAN

🔐 VPN (Virtual Private Network)

Creates a secure, encrypted tunnel over the internet.
Allows remote users to access internal network resources.

Common protocols: PPTP, L2TP, IPSec, SSL VPN

🧠 Tip: If remote workers can’t access internal resources → VPN may be misconfigured or down.
